Title: Opinion | Give the A.I. Economy a Human Touch (Published 2020) - The New York Times
description: Embracing artificial intelligence can help us create a new, equitable social contract ‚Äî but only if we remember what makes us human.
og:description: Embracing artificial intelligence can help us create a new, equitable social contract ‚Äî but only if we remember what makes us human.
twitter:description: Embracing artificial intelligence can help us create a new, equitable social contract ‚Äî but only if we remember what makes us human.
headline: Opinion | Give the A.I. Economy a Human Touch
image: [{'@context': 'https://schema.org', '@type': 'ImageObject', 'url': 'https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/12/10/multimedia/10tp-lee-2/merlin_174399318_ebaafb6b-d46b-4698-a90c-15df79f4b0b4-videoSixteenByNineJumbo1600.jpg', 'height': 900, 'width': 1600, 'contentUrl': 'https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/12/10/multimedia/10tp-lee-2/merlin_174399318_ebaafb6b-d46b-4698-a90c-15df79f4b0b4-videoSixteenByNineJumbo1600.jpg', 'caption': 'A staff member and a robot at the 2020 World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai in July.', 'creditText': 'Aly Song/Reuters'}, {'@context': 'https://schema.org', '@type': 'ImageObject', 'url': 'https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/12/10/multimedia/10tp-lee-2/merlin_174399318_ebaafb6b-d46b-4698-a90c-15df79f4b0b4-superJumbo.jpg', 'height': 1365, 'width': 2048, 'contentUrl': 'https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/12/10/multimedia/10tp-lee-2/merlin_174399318_ebaafb6b-d46b-4698-a90c-15df79f4b0b4-superJumbo.jpg', 'caption': 'A staff member and a robot at the 2020 World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai in July.', 'creditText': 'Aly Song/Reuters'}, {'@context': 'https://schema.org', '@type': 'ImageObject', 'url': 'https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/12/10/multimedia/10tp-lee-2/10tp-lee-2-mediumSquareAt3X.jpg', 'height': 1800, 'width': 1800, 'contentUrl': 'https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/12/10/multimedia/10tp-lee-2/10tp-lee-2-mediumSquareAt3X.jpg', 'caption': 'A staff member and a robot at the 2020 World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai in July.', 'creditText': 'Aly Song/Reuters'}]
author: [{'@context': 'https://schema.org', '@type': 'Person', 'url': '', 'name': 'Kai-Fu Lee'}]
article text: AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTOpinionSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTTurning PointsGive the A.I. Economy a Human TouchEmbracing artificial intelligence can help us create a new, equitable social contract ‚Äî but only if we remember what makes us human.Dec. 10, 2020A staff member and a robot at the 2020 World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai in July.Credit...Aly Song/ReutersShare full articleRead in appBy Kai-Fu LeeMr. Lee is a computer scientist.Leer en espa√±olThis is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.Turning Point: The coronavirus pandemic inspired a wave of touchless, contactless interactions ‚Äî including food delivery and medical care  ‚Äî and the replacement of human workers by computers and other technology.Automation, robotics and artificial intelligence technologies have been taking over routine tasks for years. The Covid-19 pandemic has rapidly increased that trend, driven by the triple necessities of increased productivity, lower costs and human safety. Suddenly, human contact is both undesirable and more longed for than ever. Delivery companies, plumbers and even some medical providers now boast about their ‚Äúzero contact‚Äù service, but we relish any chance we get to have an in-person meal or a face-to-face meeting.As we face the future of an A.I. economy, 2020 has taught us the importance of human connection.When I began my career in A.I. in 1983, I described A.I. in my application to the Ph.D. program at Carnegie Mellon University as ‚Äúthe quantification of the human thinking process, the explication of human behavior‚Äù and our ‚Äúfinal step‚Äù to understanding ourselves.AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTIn a way I was wrong, and in a way I was right. A.I. programs are capable of mimicking and even surpassing human brains in many tasks. But if A.I. allows us to truly understand ourselves, it will be because it liberates us from the mechanical drudgery of routine tasks and allows us to focus on our humanity and the compassionate connections between us.Sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter¬†¬†Get expert analysis of the news and a guide to the big ideas shaping the world every weekday morning.  Get it sent to your inbox.We already know that many of the jobs that are being replaced will not return, because A.I. can do them much better than people at essentially zero cost. This will generate tremendous economic value but will also result in unprecedented job displacement. In my book ‚ÄúA.I. Superpowers: China, Silicon Valley, and the New World Order,‚Äù I estimated that by 2033 A.I. and automation will be able to do 40 to 50 percent of our jobs.To prepare now for the millions of displaced jobs and tackle retraining for the new skills required when A.I. is both a co-worker and a tool, I propose the 3 R‚Äôs ‚Äî relearn, recalibrate and renaissance ‚Äî as part of a gargantuan reimagination of how we live and work to deal with the central economic issue of our time: the A.I. revolution.ImageAn A.I.-powered robotic hand, created by the research company OpenAI, learned to solve a Rubik‚Äôs cube, demonstrating a near-human level of dexterity.Credit...Matt Edge for The New York TimesFirst, and perhaps easiest, is forewarning people in endangered jobs and establishing programs for them to relearn their fields in the context of A.I. The good news is that there are plenty of ‚Äúhuman‚Äù skills that A.I. cannot master: creativity, social interaction, physically complex or dexterous work and, of course, using the A.I. tools that require human operators.AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTVocational schools need to redesign their curriculums to increase courses for sustainable jobs. Governments could take the lead and provide incentives and subsidies for those courses, rather than blindly pursuing broad-brush economic measures like universal basic income. Corporations could also provide programs, such as Amazon‚Äôs Career Choice program. This program pays up to $12,000 annually over four years for Amazon‚Äôs hourly employees to earn degrees in high-demand occupations such as aircraft mechanics, computer-aided design and nursing.Pandemic or no pandemic, the importance and number of human-centric service jobs, such as nursing, will grow as wealth and life spans increase. The World Health Organization predicts that by 2030, we will fall short of the number of health care workers required to achieve the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal of ‚Äúgood health and well-being for all‚Äù by approximately 18 million. There is an acute need to reassess such vital, yet undervalued, human-centric service roles both in terms of how they are perceived and how much they are paid. These jobs will form a bedrock for the new A.I. economy.As we prepare people for the eventual transition to an A.I.-driven economy, we will also need to recalibrate many of today‚Äôs jobs. Like software did a few decades ago, A.I. can augment humans‚Äô creative thinking with a computer‚Äôs relentless ability to churn through masses of data, hypothesize alternatives or optimize outcomes. There will not be a single, generic A.I. tool, but specific tools customized for each profession and application. We may have an A.I.-based molecule generation program for drug researchers, an A.I. advertising planner for marketers or an A.I. fact checker for journalists.Merging A.I. optimization and the human touch will reinvent many jobs and create even more. A.I. will take care of routine tasks in tandem with humans, who will carry out the tasks that require, well, humanity. For example, future doctors will still be a patient‚Äôs primary point of contact, but they will rely on A.I. diagnostic tools to determine the best treatment. This will redirect the doctor‚Äôs role into that of a compassionate caregiver, giving them more time with their patients.Just as the mobile internet led to roles like the Uber driver, the coming of A.I. will create jobs we cannot even conceive of yet. Examples today include A.I. engineers, data scientists, data-labelers and robot mechanics. We should watch for the emergence of such roles, make people aware of them and provide training for them.AdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTFinally, just as the wealthy Italian cities and merchants funded that country‚Äôs Renaissance, we must hope that A.I. will inspire a renaissance of its own. With machines taking over many duties and tasks in the new economy, A.I. will inject flexibility into traditional working patterns, allowing us to rethink what work-life balance should look like and transforming both the weekday routine and retirement thresholds. With more freedom and time in such a new social contract, people will be liberated to follow their passions, creativity and talents, and to let that personal exploration inform their careers as never before.Painters, sculptors and photographers will be able to use A.I. tools to compose, experiment, enumerate and refine their artwork. Novelists, journalists and poets will use new technologies to take their writing in previously unthought-of directions. Educators, freed from the drudgery of grading and paperwork, can finally unleash their energy to design lessons that encourage curiosity, critical thinking and creativity. A.I. programs can help teach facts and figures so that teachers can spend more time developing students‚Äô emotional intelligence.The three R‚Äôs will represent an unparalleled undertaking for humanity. Companies will need to retrain a massive number of displaced workers. Governments must raise an astronomical amount of money and redistribute it to fund this transition. Schools need to reinvent education to produce creative, social and multidisciplinary graduates. Everything must be redefined: the work ethic of society, entitlements for citizens, responsibilities for corporations and the role of governments.In all of this, the role of A.I. technologies is crucial. If we do it right, A.I. will free us to embrace not only our creativity and compassion for one another, but also our humanity.Kai-Fu Lee is a computer scientist, business leader and author, and is the chairman and chief executive of Sinovation Ventures, a venture capital investment company.The Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. We‚Äôd like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some tips. And here‚Äôs our email: letters@nytimes.com.Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.Share full articleRead in appAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTEnjoy unlimited access to all of The Times.6-month Welcome Offeroriginal price: ¬† $6.25sale price: ¬† $1/weekLearn more
name: The New York Times

Title: Behind the Paper That Led to a Google Researcher's Firing - WIRED
description: Timnit Gebru was one of seven authors on a study that examined prior research on training artificial intelligence models to understand language.
keywords: ['business', 'artificial intelligence', 'ai hub', 'ethics', 'text analysis', 'text generation', 'alphabet', 'google', 'research', 'consumer services', 'text', 'machine learning', 'natural language processing', 'algorithms', 'deep learning', 'web']
og:description: Timnit Gebru was one of seven authors on a study that examined prior research on training artificial intelligence models to understand language.
twitter:description: Timnit Gebru was one of seven authors on a study that examined prior research on training artificial intelligence models to understand language.
headline: Behind the Paper That Led to a Google Researcher‚Äôs Firing
author: [{'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Tom Simonite', 'sameAs': 'https://www.wired.com/author/tom-simonite/'}]
article text: Tom SimoniteBusinessDec 8, 2020 4:39 PMBehind the Paper That Led to a Google Researcher‚Äôs FiringTimnit Gebru was one of seven authors on a study that examined prior research on training artificial intelligence models to understand language.Timnit Gebru, a prominent artificial intelligence researcher, says she was fired after refusing to retract or take her name off an academic paper.Photograph: CODY O'LOUGHLIN/ReduxSave this storySaveSave this storySaveThe AI Database ‚ÜíApplicationEthicsText analysisText generationCompanyAlphabetGoogleEnd UserResearchSectorConsumer servicesResearchSource DataTextTechnologyMachine learningNatural language processingEarlier this year, Google artificial intelligence researcher Timnit Gebru sent a Twitter message to University of Washington professor Emily Bender. Gebru asked Bender if she had written about the ethical questions raised by recent advances in AI that processes text. Bender hadn‚Äôt, but the pair fell into a conversation about the limitations of such technology, such as evidence it can replicate biased language found online.Bender found the DM discussion enlivening and suggested building it into an academic paper. ‚ÄúI hoped to provoke the next turn in the conversation,‚Äù Bender says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen all this excitement and success, let‚Äôs step back and see what the possible risks are and what we can do.‚Äù The draft was written in a month with five additional coauthors from Google and academia and was submitted in October to an academic conference. It would soon become one of the most notorious research works in AI.The Dark Side of Big Tech‚Äôs Funding for AI ResearchBy Tom SimoniteLast week, Gebru said she was fired by Google after objecting to a manager‚Äôs request to retract or remove her name from the paper. Google‚Äôs head of AI said the work ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt meet our bar for publication.‚Äù Since then, more than 2,200 Google employees have signed a letter demanding more transparency into the company‚Äôs handling of the draft. Saturday, Gebru‚Äôs manager, Google AI researcher Samy Bengio, wrote on Facebook that he was ‚Äústunned,‚Äù declaring ‚ÄúI stand by you, Timnit.‚Äù AI researchers outside Google have publicly castigated the company‚Äôs treatment of Gebru.Trending NowWhy Some Cities Are Banning Facial Recognition TechnologyThe furor gave the paper that catalyzed Gebru‚Äôs sudden exit an aura of unusual power. It circulated in AI circles¬†like samizdat. But the most remarkable thing about the 12-page document, seen by WIRED, is how uncontroversial it is. The paper does not attack Google or its technology and seems unlikely to have hurt the company‚Äôs reputation if Gebru had been allowed to publish it with her Google affiliation.The paper surveys previous research on the limitations of AI systems that analyze and generate language. It doesn‚Äôt present new experiments. The authors cite prior studies showing that language AI can consume vast amounts of electricity and echo unsavory biases found in online text. And they suggest ways AI researchers can be more careful with the technology, including by better documenting the data used to create such systems.‚ÄúIt is hard to see what could trigger an uproar in any lab, let alone lead to someone losing their job over it.‚ÄùJulien Cornebise, honorary associate professor, University College LondonGoogle‚Äôs contributions to the field‚Äîsome now deployed in its search engine‚Äîare referenced but not singled out for special criticism. One of the studies cited, showing evidence of bias in language AI, was published by Google researchers earlier this year.‚ÄúThis article is a very solid and well-researched piece of work,‚Äù says Julien Cornebise, an honorary associate professor at University College London who has seen a draft of the paper. ‚ÄúIt is hard to see what could trigger an uproar in any lab, let alone lead to someone losing their job over it.‚ÄùGoogle‚Äôs reaction might be evidence that company leaders feel more vulnerable to ethical critiques than Gebru and others realized‚Äîor that her departure was about more than just the paper. The company did not respond to a request for comment. In a blog post Monday, members of Google‚Äôs AI ethics research team suggested that managers had turned Google‚Äôs internal research-review process against Gebru. They showed major progress on tasks such as answering questions or generating text by having machine-learning algorithms digest billions of words of text scraped from the web. But they can number-crunch their way to impressive feats such as answering questions or generating fluid new text.AdvertisementOne such system, Google‚Äôs BERT, is used to improve how the company‚Äôs search engine handles long queries. All of the authors appear to still work at Google.In the paper that precipitated Gebru‚Äôs exit, she and her coauthors urge AI developers to be more cautious with language projects. They recommend researchers do more to document the text used to create language AI and the limitations of systems made with it. They point readers to some recently proposed ideas for labeling AI systems with data on their accuracy and weaknesses. One cocreated by Gebru at Google is called model cards for model reporting and has been adopted by Google‚Äôs cloud division. alternativeHeadline: Timnit Gebru was one of seven authors on a study that examined prior research on training artificial intelligence models to understand language.
itemListElement: [{'@type': 'ListItem', 'position': 1, 'name': 'Business', 'item': 'https://www.wired.com/business/'}, {'@type': 'ListItem', 'position': 2, 'name': 'machine learning', 'item': 'https://www.wired.com/tag/machine-learning/'}, {'@type': 'ListItem', 'position': 3, 'name': 'Behind the Paper That Led to a Google Researcher‚Äôs Firing'}]
articleBody:
Bender found the DM discussion enlivening and suggested building it into an academic paper. ‚ÄúI hoped to provoke the next turn in the conversation,‚Äù Bender says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen all this excitement and success, let‚Äôs step back and see what the possible risks are and what we can do.‚Äù The draft was written in a month with five additional coauthors from Google and academia and was submitted in October to an academic conference. It would soon become one of the most notorious research works in AI.
Last week, Gebru said she was fired by Google after objecting to a manager‚Äôs request to retract or remove her name from the paper. Google‚Äôs head of AI said the work ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt meet our bar for publication.‚Äù Since then, more than 2,200 Google employees have signed a letter demanding more transparency into the company‚Äôs handling of the draft. Saturday, Gebru‚Äôs manager, Google AI researcher Samy Bengio, wrote on Facebook that he was ‚Äústunned,‚Äù declaring ‚ÄúI stand by you, Timnit.‚Äù AI researchers outside Google have publicly castigated the company‚Äôs treatment of Gebru.
The furor gave the paper that catalyzed Gebru‚Äôs sudden exit an aura of unusual power. It circulated in AI circles¬†like samizdat. But the most remarkable thing about the 12-page document, seen by WIRED, is how uncontroversial it is. The paper does not attack Google or its technology and seems unlikely to have hurt the company‚Äôs reputation if Gebru had been allowed to publish it with her Google affiliation.
The paper surveys previous research on the limitations of AI systems that analyze and generate language. It doesn‚Äôt present new experiments. The authors cite prior studies showing that language AI can consume vast amounts of electricity and echo unsavory biases found in online text. And they suggest ways AI researchers can be more careful with the technology, including by better documenting the data used to create such systems.
Google‚Äôs contributions to the field‚Äîsome now deployed in its search engine‚Äîare referenced but not singled out for special criticism. One of the studies cited, showing evidence of bias in language AI, was published by Google researchers earlier this year.
‚ÄúThis article is a very solid and well-researched piece of work,‚Äù says Julien Cornebise, an honorary associate professor at University College London who has seen a draft of the paper. ‚ÄúIt is hard to see what could trigger an uproar in any lab, let alone lead to someone losing their job over it.‚Äù
Google‚Äôs reaction might be evidence that company leaders feel more vulnerable to ethical critiques than Gebru and others realized‚Äîor that her departure was about more than just the paper. The company did not respond to a request for comment. In a blog post Monday, members of Google‚Äôs AI ethics research team suggested that managers had turned Google‚Äôs internal research-review process against Gebru. Gebru said last week that she may have been removed for criticizing Google‚Äôs diversity programs and suggesting in a recent group email that coworkers stop participating in them.
The draft paper that set the controversy in motion is titled ‚ÄúOn the Dangers of Stochastic Parrots: Can Language Models Be Too Big?‚Äù (It includes a parrot emoji after the question mark.) It turns a critical eye on one of the most lively strands of AI research.
Tech companies such as Google have invested heavily in AI since the early 2010s, when researchers discovered they could make speech and image recognition much more accurate using a technique called machine learning. These algorithms can refine their performance at a task, say transcribing speech, by digesting example data annotated with labels. An approach called deep learning enabled stunning new results by coupling learning algorithms with much larger collections of example data and more powerful computers.
In the past few years, researchers figured out how to super-scale machine learning models for language too. They showed major progress on tasks such as answering questions or generating text by having machine-learning algorithms digest billions of words of text scraped from the web. Those systems operate on the statistical patterns of language. They don‚Äôt understand the world in the way humans do and can still make blunders that seem obvious to a person. But they can number-crunch their way to impressive feats such as answering questions or generating fluid new text.
One such system, Google‚Äôs BERT, is used to improve how the company‚Äôs search engine handles long queries. Microsoft said it will license a system called GPT-3 from independent lab OpenAI that is also being tapped by entrepreneurs to write emails and ad copy.
That progress has prompted other researchers to question the limitations and possible societal effects of this new language technology. Gebru, Bender and their coauthors set out to draw this work together and suggest how the research community should respond.
The authors point to previous research that calculated that training a large language model can consume as much energy as a car does from construction to junk yard, and a project that showed AI could mimic online conspiracy theorists
Another study cited by the paper was published by Google researchers earlier this year, and showed limitations of BERT, the company‚Äôs own language model. The team, which did not include Gebru, showed that BERT tended to associate phrases referring to disabilities such as cerebral palsy or blindness with negative language. All of the authors appear to still work at Google.
In the paper that precipitated Gebru‚Äôs exit, she and her coauthors urge AI developers to be more cautious with language projects. They recommend researchers do more to document the text used to create language AI and the limitations of systems made with it. They point readers to some recently proposed ideas for labeling AI systems with data on their accuracy and weaknesses. One cocreated by Gebru at Google is called model cards for model reporting and has been adopted by Google‚Äôs cloud division. The paper asks researchers building language systems to consider not only the perspective of AI developers, but also those of people outside the field who may be subjected to the systems‚Äô outputs or judgments.
In his statement on Gebru‚Äôs departure last week claiming the paper was of poor quality, Google‚Äôs head of research, Jeff Dean, said it failed to cite research on making more efficient language models and ways to mitigate bias.
Bender says the authors included 128 citations and will likely add more. Such additions are common practice during the academic publishing process and are not usually reason to withdraw a paper. She and other AI researchers also say that despite Dean‚Äôs comment, the field is far from inventing a way to reliably eradicate language bias.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs still work in progress because the bias takes many forms,‚Äù says Oren Etzioni, CEO of the Allen Institute for AI, which has done its own research on the topic, including some cited in the draft paper. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a recognition from pretty much everybody who works in the field that these models are becoming increasingly influential and that we have an ethical obligation to deploy them responsibly.‚Äù

article text:
Panel Details Global Artificial Intelligence Arms Race


John Grady 
December 9, 2020 11:40 AM 

Harnessing artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies has become the new arms race among the great powers, a Hudson Institute panel on handling big data in military operations said Monday.
Speaking at the online forum, Richard Schultz, director of the international security program in the Fletcher School at Tufts University, said, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs the way [Russian President Vladimir] Putin looks at it. I don‚Äôt think we have a choice‚Äù but to view it the same way.
He added in answer to a question that ‚Äúthe data in information space is enormous,‚Äù so finding tools to filter out what‚Äôs not necessary is critical. U.S. Special Operations Command is already using AI to do what in the old days was called political or psychological warfare, in addition to targeting, he added.

SOCOM Commander Army Gen. Richard Clarke said that, in recent conversations he has had with commanders in Afghanistan, between 2001 and 2018 ‚Äú70 percent of their time was putting bomb on target.‚Äù But now, through better use of AI for speedy and precise targeting and a greater understanding of the effectiveness of information operations, they have reversed that ratio.
Clarke and Schultz co-authored the recent monograph ‚ÄúBig Data at War‚Äù that details what SOCOM gained in moving out with AI and machine learning.
Bryan Clark of the Hudson Institute said during the event that the lessons learned from Special Operations Command work in Afghanistan ‚Äì starting in 2004 but accelerating in 2008 ‚Äì is being felt across the Department of Defense. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs decision-centric warfare‚Äù versus ‚Äúattrition-centric warfare.‚Äù He compared it to ‚Äúmaneuver warfare in the information domain.‚Äù He specifically cited the value of Project Maven as improving a field commander‚Äôs ability to more effectively command and control his unit‚Äôs operation in conflict ‚Äì from when, what and where to fire, to not shooting at all.
Project Maven is a Pentagon project using machine learning to sort through masses of intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance data ‚Äì unmanned systems video, paper, computer hard drives, thumb drives and more ‚Äì collected by the department and intelligence agencies for operational use across the services. It has sometimes been called ‚Äúalgorithmic warfare.‚Äù
In a combat situation, Clark said, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre not trying to kill every bad guy out there‚Äù but rather are targeting a leader or a group of leaders. AI has already gained a strong foothold in logistics and maintenance in Pentagon thinking and is now making its way to commanders.
‚ÄúMaven has made some inroads [because] it is actively giving them courses of actions‚Äù and even parallel courses of actions to take simultaneously to further confuse an enemy.
Clark added that for more than a decade private industry has applied AI and machine learning to its operations. In doing so, businesses found out how to conduct tasks work with technology and then use the human workforce for other tasks, creating greater output overall.
Maven, however, has had something of a checkered past, particularly after Google withdrew from the project in 2018. Schultz said ‚Äúthe big issue is what happens to Maven a year or so from now when it goes out of business,‚Äù as expected under current budget plans.
With that being said, Schultz added that the Army‚Äôs 82nd Airborne Division and its XVIII Corps ‚Äúwant to be the first‚Äù division and corps to apply AI and machine learning across the board, from planning to operations to sustainment. He said the commanders had a special operations background before moving into their new positions, and that experience made them more familiar with what these technologies could do for them.
Clarke said a number of these AI and machine learning ideas would be tested in the Army‚Äôs Project Convergence next year.
‚ÄúCommanders have to set the tone [to allow] ideas to bubble up,‚Äù Clarke said of his experience in SOCOM. They have to build the cadre of data scientists and coders and the mid-level managers to become truly effective and sustain efficiencies. When that‚Äôs in place, they can share best practices with other units.
All agreed that, even with the adaptation of AI and machine learning to military operations, forward presence would remain important. How many forces, however, could be reduced when forces like Marines have more tools in their hands to succeed. Clark added, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre definitely seeing that synergy‚Äù in the Marine Corps on applying AI to operations.
‚ÄúWe can prevail‚Äù against the Chinese and the Russians in the new arms race, Schultz said. ‚ÄúWe just need to be able to harness [artificial intelligence].‚Äù
Clarke said his command was putting its ‚Äúmoney where its mouth is‚Äù when it comes to investing and operating with advanced technologies. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have a choice.‚Äù

Related

In contrast to the Department of Defense, China¬† "effectively copied" Silicon Valley's quick-decision investment strategies with start-ups in its technology race with the United‚Ä¶March 8, 2021In "China"U.S. Needs to Demonstrate Ability to Assist Taiwan, Congressman SaysThe U.S. needs to show Beijing that it can stop China if Chinese President Xi Jinping were to risk a cross-strait invasion to bring Taiwan under Chinese control, a congressman involved with military innovation this week. The United States must realize¬†that it cannot rely on the Taiwanese people to be‚Ä¶November 23, 2022In "China"Panel: Artificial Intelligence Promises to Help Sailors Make Better Decisions FasterThe Navy is thinking about artificial intelligence in two ways: the infrastructure to make unmanned systems work and technology meant to enhance how sailor and their commanders make decisions, a panel of technical and policy experts said Tuesday. The output provided by AI is there help the human or supplement‚Ä¶October 18, 2022In "China"  


 



 



John Grady


John Grady, a former managing editor of Navy Times, retired as director of communications for the Association of the United States Army. His reporting on national defense and national security has appeared on Breaking Defense, GovExec.com, NextGov.com, DefenseOne.com, Government Executive and USNI News.

Title: Artificial Intelligence Improves America's Food System - USDA.gov
description: Technology is everywhere in the 21st century, and America‚Äôs food system is no exception.
og:description: Technology is everywhere in the 21st century, and America‚Äôs food system is no exception.
twitter:description: Technology is everywhere in the 21st century, and America‚Äôs food system is no exception.
article text:
Posted by Scott Elliott, Agricultural Research Service Office of Communications in
    
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Research and Science
Technology

 Dec 10, 2020 


Among other things, the AI Institute for Next Generation Food Systems will study the nutrients and molecular structure of foods and determine how to breed plants for optimal production. (Photo by Peggy Greb)

Technology is everywhere in the 21st century, and America‚Äôs food system is no exception.
Scientists with the USDA Agricultural Research Service‚Äôs (ARS) Western Human Nutrition Research Center (WHNRC), at the University of California (UC) ‚Äì Davis, have joined forces with over 40 researchers from six organizations to form an institute that will use artificial intelligence (AI) to create the next-generation food system. The team, led by UC Davis, also includes UC Berkeley, Cornell University, and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The project is funded by a $20 million grant from USDA‚Äôs National Institute of Food and Agriculture.
‚ÄúThe AI Institute for Next Generation Food Systems (AIFS) is dedicated to accelerating the use of artificial intelligence to optimally produce, process, and distribute safe and nutritious food,‚Äù said Dr. Danielle Lemay, a USDA research molecular biologist at WHNRC.
The institute‚Äôs goals include using molecular breeding to improve crop yield, quality, and disease resistance; using AI applications and other technology, such as sensing platforms and robotics, to reduce resource use; enhancing food safety; and developing tools for consumers to make personalized health decisions.
According to Lemay, AIFS is developing AI to determine how to breed plants for optimal production, how to better manage water and nitrogen use, and how to forecast crop yields. For food processing, AI will help inform decisions about cleaning to improve sanitation and reduce the spread of pathogens. AI will also help reduce energy use and food waste by advising against transporting food that may not be used at its destination. In nutrition, AI will predict the ingredients from photos in a consumer‚Äôs own food journal.
‚ÄúAlso, one of our goals is to help young people understand the value of where their food comes from, and to see themselves in future agriculture and food careers,‚Äù Lemay said. ‚ÄúThe opportunity is to create more workers at all levels who have both AI and food system expertise. This includes engagement at every level ‚Äì from K through 12 and at community colleges, summer internships, and field days with farmers.‚Äù
Lemay, who leads the institute‚Äôs nutrition research, said AIFS is unique in that no other AI research effort has included human nutrition. ‚ÄúOur grand challenge is to apply AI technologies to better capture what people are eating, to determine the nutrients and molecular structure of that food, and to predict health outcomes of those dietary choices.‚Äù
‚ÄúIn the future, we hope that AI can be used to personalize information on health status, genotype, and microbiome,‚Äù said Lemay.
This research supports multiple themes outlined in the USDA Science Blueprint (PDF, 2.6 MB), which moves us closer to meeting the goals outlined in USDA‚Äôs Agriculture Innovation Agenda.

Title: Artificial-intelligence research escalates amid calls for caution - Nature.com
description: A look at one of the most rapidly advancing and controversial topics in scientific research.
og:description: A look at one of the most rapidly advancing and controversial topics in scientific research.
twitter:description: Nature - A look at one of the most rapidly advancing and controversial topics in scientific research.
article text:
NATURE INDEX
09 December 2020

Artificial-intelligence research escalates amid calls for caution


                    A look at one of the most rapidly advancing and controversial topics in scientific research.
                




    By
    
        
        
                Bec Crew0




Bec Crew


Senior editor




View author publications

You can also search for this author in PubMed
¬†Google Scholar













Twitter





Facebook





Email












Credit: Taj Francis


This supplement explores artificial intelligence (AI), one of the most rapidly advancing and controversial topics in scientific research. Driven by escalating computing power, expanding data sets, and algorithms of unprecedented sophistication, the number of journal and conference papers referring to AI in the Dimensions from Digital Science database increased by more than 600% between 2000 and 2019. Almost one-third of those papers date from 2017 to 2019. The year 2020 is set to be the biggest yet, both in terms of research published and money invested.

Nature Index 2020 Artificial intelligence
In these pages, we look at emerging technologies that are transforming the ways we live and work, and the growing concern around their potential misuse. We consider the collective responsibility of all who are engaged in the research and development of AI, including publishers, to ensure that it is carried out ethically and inclusively.We are pleased to bring you an experiment in AI-powered curation of content from the Nature Index publisher, Springer Nature, related to drug discovery with AI, as well as an account of the current and future uses of AI of scholarly publishing. We also describe the work of some of the most innovative researchers in the field, and the leading institutions based on output in the 82 high-quality natural-sciences journals tracked by the index.It is important to note that the Nature Index lens on AI research is a very focused one; the articles picked up by our database search concern specific applications of AI in the life sciences, physical sciences, chemistry, and Earth and environmental sciences. Between 2015 and 2019, these highly specialized articles comprised just 1.2% of all AI-related articles in the Dimensions database. The leading institutions for AI in the Nature Index are quite different from those with the most AI-related research in Dimensions, with Western institutions dominating the former and China the latter.

Nature 588, S101 (2020)

Title: Poland joins the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence - Digital Affairs ‚Äì Chancellery of the Prime Minister - Gov.pl
description: During the plenary summit held in Montreal, Poland joined the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence and its responsible development.
og:description: During the plenary summit held in Montreal, Poland joined the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence and its responsible development.
twitter:description: During the plenary summit held in Montreal, Poland joined the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence and its responsible development.
article text:
Poland joins the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence
08.12.2020
During the plenary summit held in Montreal, Poland joined the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence and its responsible development. 







The Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence (GPAI) is an initiative that leverages international cooperation on key research and projects. The organisation aims at developing a responsible and trustworthy artificial intelligence.
Breakthrough technology
The founding members of the GPAI are Australia, Canada, France, Germany, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, New Zealand, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, Slovenia, the United Kingdom, the United States and the European Union (as a single entity enacting international law). On 4 December, the Partnership was joined by new members during a plenary summit ‚Äì¬† Poland, Brazil, the Netherlands and Spain.
‚ÄúOn behalf of the Ministerial Council of the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence, I would like to welcome Poland as a new member. We are certain that Poland will bring a wealth of knowledge and experience in the field of artificial intelligence to this ground-breaking initiative,‚Äù wrote Elizabeth Thomas-Raynaud, Secretary of the GPAI.
Poland‚Äôs accession into the Partnership is a result of Polish involvement in the field of AI in international forums, including the work of the AIGO (OECD) - Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and HLEG (EC) ‚Äì High Level Expert Group on Artificial Intelligence, spanning more than two years.
The experts representing Poland on the GPAI forum are attorney Robert Kroplewski, plenipotentiary of the Minister of Digital Affairs for Information Society and Prof. Bogumi≈Ç Kami≈Ñski, Warsaw School of Economics.
AI development in Poland
‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly turning into one of the most influential technologies in the world today. It changes the way people work and has a significant impact on national economies. Taking advantage of its full potential requires international cooperation and coordination,‚Äù claims Minister Marek Zag√≥rski, Secretary of State in the Chancellery of the Prime Minister.
New technologies and solutions based on AI have an increasing impact on building the capacity of national economies. Poland also wants to get on this bandwagon.
To this end, the Polish Government has enacted the "Policy for the Development of Artificial Intelligence in Poland‚Äù ‚Äì a document, the goal of which is to achieve this objective, which emerged as a result of months-long consultations. The document has already been approved by the Committee of the Council of Ministers for Digital Affairs, currently pending approval by the Council of Ministers.
The ‚ÄúPolicy for the Development of Artificial Intelligence in Poland‚Äù supports and complements other documents, including the Responsible Development Strategy, the European Commission's Coordinated Plan on Artificial Intelligence, as well as the work of international organisations, including the OECD.¬†¬† ¬†
Our document takes into account not only the international, legal, technical or organisational dimension of the use of artificial intelligence, but also its ethical aspects,‚Äù says Minister Marek Zag√≥rski, Secretary of State in the Chancellery of the Prime Minister.¬†‚ÄúOur mission is to support the society, companies, representatives of the academia and public administration in taking advantage of opportunities related to AI development, while ensuring the protection of human dignity and conditions for fair competition in this global race,‚Äù he added.
The document defines actions and objectives for Poland in the short term (2023), medium term (2027) and long term (post-2027) perspective.
We divided them into six areas:
AI and society¬†‚Äì activities, whose goal is to make Poland one of the major beneficiaries of a data-based economy, while raising awareness of the need for the continuous improvement of digital competences.
AI and innovative companies¬†‚Äì support for Polish AI companies, including the development of financing mechanisms, as well as ways of cooperation between start-ups and the government.
AI and science¬†‚Äì support for the Polish scientific and research community in designing interdisciplinary challenges or solutions in the area of AI, including activities aimed at preparing AI expert staff.
AI and education¬†‚Äì activities starting in primary schooling and continuing until the university level ‚Äì course curricula for people at risk of losing their jobs as a result of development of new technologies, educational grants.
AI and international cooperation¬†‚Äì activities supporting Polish companies in the field of AI and technology development in the international arena.
AI and the public sector¬†‚Äì support for the public sector in the implementation of contracts concerning AI, better coordination of activities and further development of programmes such as GovTech Polska.

Title: Four new countries join the Global Partnership for Artificial Intelligence - Intelligence artificielle - Actu IA

article text:
Four new countries join the Global Partnership for Artificial Intelligence                    




Thomas Calvi
 - 



8 d√©cembre 2020





0                        








The first summit of the Global Partnership for Artificial Intelligence (GPIA) was held in Montreal on December 3 and 4. On this occasion, the Franco-Canadian PMIA initiative was expanded to include four new member states, Spain, the Netherlands, Poland and Brazil.

Officially launched on 15 June 2020, the PMIA has 15 founding members: France, Canada, Australia, the Republic of Korea, the European Union, Germany, Italy, India, Japan, Mexico, New Zealand, Singapore, Slovenia, the United Kingdom, the United States and the European Union. The goal of this international, multi-stakeholder initiative is to promote the responsible use of AI in a spirit of respect for human rights, inclusion, diversity, innovation and economic growth. To achieve these objectives, member countries work through the PMIA to build bridges between theory and practice, to support research activities or the application of trusted artificial intelligence.
Democratic values, human rights, accountability, transparency, diversity, inclusiveness and privacy are at the core of the values of PMIA and its work.
On the occasion of this first summit, the PMIA bodies (steering committee and council) were officially set up and the first works undertaken by the researchers were presented in plenary session. The experts are notably supported by two centres of expertise located in Paris, hosted by Inria, and in Montreal, hosted by the Montreal International Centre of Expertise for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (CIMIA). Working groups focus on 4 main themes: ‚ÄúFuture of Work‚Äù and ‚ÄúInnovation & Commercialization‚Äù in Paris, and ‚ÄúResponsible AI‚Äù and ‚ÄúData Governance‚Äù in Montreal. An additional group dedicated to Covid-19 was launched in 2020 to help address the global health crisis.
This session also confirmed the momentum behind the initiative. Spain, the Netherlands, Poland and Brazil joined the initiative, bringing the number of PMIA member states to 19. The newly elected Steering Committee members include 5 States (France, Canada, United States, Italy and Japan) and 6 AI experts (see list below).
France, which has been designated as the incoming vice-presidency, will assume the presidency in 2022. Canada will hold the presidency until the fall of 2021. The next PMIA Summit will be held in Paris.
List of experts sitting on the PMIA Steering Committee :


Baroness Joanna Shields (Chair of the Multistakeholder Experts Group Plenary)
Ashley J. Llorens (Science)
Francesca Rossi (Industry)
Carly Kind (Civil Society)
Christina J.Colclough (Labour / Social Partners)
Association for the Advancement of AI (AAAI) (international organization)

author: {'url': '/voices/brandi-vincent/14441/', '@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Brandi Vincent'}
article text:
AI Accountability, Tech Talent Pipeline In-Focus for Next Congress, Staffers Say
                    Wangbar/Shutterstock.com
                  
Sponsor Message

Sponsor Message


      
  Get the latest federal technology news delivered to your inbox.

    emailStay Connected
Sponsor Message

Sponsor Message

Featured eBooks
  Cyber Workforce
            Read Now
              Law Enforcement TechRead NowAI in the WorkplaceRead Now









    
  


By

Brandi Vincent,Defense Technology Correspondent







































            
              
                
  



  By


Brandi Vincent

|

             December 7, 2020
            

Officials recognize setbacks the pandemic is having on STEM education.






                  Artificial Intelligence
                









                  Workforce
                









                  Congress
                












































Several Senate and House staffers suspect the responsible use of artificial intelligence and America‚Äôs technology workforce pipeline could land among big-ticket tech policy items for the next Congress, which is set to start early next month.¬†‚ÄúI would love to see us putting out proposals related to bias [in AI] and related to the future of work‚Äîthose are two areas that we have not played in too much yet,‚Äù Sam Mulopulos, a legislative assistant for Sen. Rob Portman, R-Ohio, said during a virtual event hosted by the Wilson Center Thursday.¬†He spoke alongside a few other Congressional staff members in the AI caucuses.¬†The group reflected on AI-accelerating accomplishments that unfolded through the current but soon-to-end session of Congress. Mulopulos noted the Senate AI Caucus launched in 2019 and before this session closes, all six of its legislative proposals related to the emerging technology are poised to pass through the National Defense Authorization Act, which could soon be up for a vote.¬†While AI is widely used commercially and increasingly leveraged by federal agencies, it remains on-the-rise and less-regulated. Congress members‚Äô views on the tech are generally mixed across the aisle.Explainable AI was defined in American law for the first time in the 2020 NDAA, through legislation partly pushed forward by Portman. Signaling back to that, staff director for the Science Space and Technology Committee‚Äôs Subcommittee on Research and Technology Dahlia Sokolov said there‚Äôs still a dire need for consensus definitions for other descriptives connected to trustworthy AI.‚ÄúBias is probably an easier one, because you get statistical results,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut a lot of these terms you use around trustworthiness‚Äîtransparency and explainability are two big ones‚Äîwe don't actually have agreed upon definitions, so we really need to start at first principles: what do we even agree these things mean and how do we measure them?‚ÄùThe realm of responsible AI is also a sharp focus for Sen. Martin Heinrich, D-N.M, according to the lawmaker‚Äôs Military Legislative Assistant Sean Duggan. Offering an example of potential implications in this area, Duggan highlighted the need to be able to trace back an algorithm‚Äôs role or choice in denying someone a loan.¬†‚ÄúI think that AI will only be as useful or accepted as people feel comfortable that it is a part of our everyday lives,‚Äù Duggan said. ‚ÄúAnd if you can't explain that to somebody on the street, then I think that a lot of its usage, and future can be limited. That's one big focus of the senator‚Äîand hopefully the Senate AI caucus next year‚Äîhow do we increase familiarity, trustworthiness and accountability with AI?‚ÄùTechnology evaluations steered by the National Institutes of Standards and Technology could enable new learnings on bias in AI, Mulopulos added, suggesting one on algorithms used to make housing-related decisions and any racial disparities that might arise, prompted by Duggan‚Äôs point. AI and accountability in its usage has also emerged as an Executive Branch priority. President Trump signed an executive order last week guiding agencies‚Äô efforts with the technology, with the intent to foster public trust.The panelists agreed that the future of work and broadening America‚Äôs technology-focused education pipeline will likely also be in-focus for Congress next year.¬†‚ÄúPart of what we need to do is start really looking internally about how we can make sure our children ... are educated enough to tackle these jobs,‚Äù Mike Richards, deputy chief of staff for Rep. Pete Olson, R-Texas, said. A focus could be placed on further incentivizing kids to gain interest in science, technology, engineering and math‚Äîor STEM‚Äîeducation paths, he said.Sokolov added that while the federal role in STEM education and the nation‚Äôs talent pool is small compared to the state and local levels, it‚Äôs not nonexistent. The Science Committee will look back on current incentives, scholarships and fellowships in this space to address ongoing challenges that come with building a future-facing workforce, she noted. They‚Äôll also be ‚Äúthinking harder and more deeply about this diversity issue in terms of what really works.‚Äù‚ÄúI think we all recognize, too, that this pandemic has set us back on STEM education, and in particular, equal access across the socio-economic spectrum,‚Äù Sokolov said. ‚ÄúAnd it's going to be a real challenge to build our way back out of that.‚Äù

Title: AI Digital Oilfield Lab Opens at University of Houston - University of Houston

og:description: Project Teams Students, Faculty and Industry to Create Innovative Solutions
article text:
AI Digital Oilfield Lab Opens at University of HoustonProject Teams Students, Faculty and Industry to Create Innovative Solutions  
By Jeannie Kever 713-743-0778December 10, 2020


The new Artificial Intelligence Industry Incubator and Digital Oilfield Lab at the University of Houston at Sugar Land offers students, faculty and industry collaborators to use artificial sensors and other equipment.Key players in bringing the lab and incubator to the College of Technology are, from left, Dean Anthony Ambler; Associate Dean for Research and Graduate Studies George Zouridakis; Konrad Konarski, chair and director of operations at the AI Innovation Consortium; Associate Professor Amaury Lendasse;  Professor of Practice David Crawley; and Associate Professor of Instruction Brian Mehring.The energy industry is rapidly becoming more dependent on the use of data and artificial intelligence. A new Artificial Intelligence Industry Incubator and Digital Oilfield Lab at the University of Houston will allow students, faculty and industry professionals to create the technologies and other solutions needed for the future.
The lab, a project of the UH College of Technology and the AI Innovation Consortium (AIIC), will open later this month, focused on projects that can promote safety and efficiency by, in part, relying on machine learning and other forms of AI to reduce the human footprint in the field. The consortium is based in Louisville, Kentucky, and made up of universities including UH, Pennsylvania State University, the University of Louisville and Louisiana State University, along with a number of corporations.
The Artificial Intelligence Industry Incubator and Digital Oilfield Lab will be housed at the University of Houston at Sugar Land, an instructional site of the University of Houston, and is part of the College of Technology‚Äôs Advanced Technology and Innovation Laboratory.
College of Technology Dean Anthony Ambler said the project and membership in the AI Innovation Consortium are a win for both students and industry.
‚ÄúAs subject matter experts in energy technology, our expertise in AI machine learning and robotic process automation and project management has already generated advances for the consortium‚Äôs industry partners and for our students,‚Äù he said. ¬†
David Crawley, professor of practice in the College of Technology, said the partnership will conduct commercial research and prototyping for the next generation of energy innovation. But beyond the commercial applications, he said, it will support students with workforce skills, industry internships and incubator activities.
‚ÄúThe laboratory and incubator will allow our students to contribute to the various applied research and proof of concept work currently underway and in the future,‚Äù Crawley said. ‚ÄúThis includes working with the AIIC‚Äôs commercial partners to create opportunities to move their incubator experience and advanced academic background into jobs at participating operations.‚Äù¬†
The AIIC has built similar incubator programs at Penn State for industrial manufacturing and the University of Louisville for autonomous driving. For the program at UH, consortium leaders said several companies already have agreed to collaborate on projects focused on AI-powered predictive analytics, AI for visual inspection, and health and safety.
‚ÄúThis incubator program emphasizes the need to build projects grounded in clear business value, with technologically rich and hands-on initiatives, and an engaging industry/academia partnership,‚Äù said Konrad Konarski, chair and director of operations at AIIC. ‚ÄúThis allows us to focus on the most relevant AI technologies that have immediate impact and value to the oil and gas industry.‚Äù
Kris Skrinak, a leader in AI who is global machine learning segment lead for Amazon Web Services and a member of the AIIC advisory council, said the UH program is important for industry in several ways.
‚ÄúThese types of AI programs help strengthen efforts for broader industry adoption and are assisting in cultivating the next generation of AI experts in the workforce,‚Äù he said.


Categories:
                Energy, Research, Top Stories

Title: Take the 5th STEM challenge: Understand AI by playing noughts and crosses - Evening Standard
description: Learn how to never lose at noughts and crosses ‚Äì and how that helps you understand AI¬†
keywords: STEM Challenge, AI, Artificial Intelligence, Science, Engineering, Technology, University, maths
og:description: Learn how to never lose at noughts and crosses ‚Äì and how that helps you understand AI¬†
twitter:description: Learn how to never lose at noughts and crosses ‚Äì and how that helps you understand AI¬†
headline: STEM Challenge #5: Understand AI by playing noughts and crosses
author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Jason Deans', 'url': 'https://www.standard.co.uk/author/jason-deans'}
article text:
Future London | The STEM ProjectTake the 5th STEM challenge: learn about artificial intelligence and video games by playing noughts and crossesLearn how to never lose at noughts and crosses ‚Äì and how that helps you understand AI¬†









In association withNever lose: these rules will ensure you never lose at noughts and crosses - and help you understand AI Illustration by Garry Parsons @Meiklejohn.co.ukJason Deans8 December 2020Welcome to the fifth part of the Future London STEM Project ‚Äî our series for young people that considers the impact of science, technology, engineering and maths on our world, and explains how you can get involved. Every fortnight we share a STEM challenge for you to try at home, and meet inspiring people who tell us about their STEM jobs and explain how they developed their skills through school, university and beyond. ¬†Today we‚Äôre working with the Game AI Research Group at Queen Mary University of London and taking a look at artificial intelligence and the key role it plays in the creation of video games. We‚Äôre also meeting Lucrezia Del Zompo who uses artificial intelligence in her job and in her studies.Mike Cook, 33, a research fellow working in Queen Mary‚Äôs Game AI Research Group, has helped us with our latest STEM Challenge, in which we show you how to never lose at noughts and crosses ‚Äî and how to simulate how AI can do the same thing ‚Äî using just a piece of paper with a set of instructions. ¬†In our third STEM challenge, a magic card trick, we learned how computer algorithms work: how by following a series of logical steps, they guarantee a desired outcome to solving a problem. ¬†AI is often used to describe machines or computers that mimic the learning and problem-solving functions of the human mind. Devices with AI are known as ‚Äúintelligent agents‚Äù ‚Äî capable of assessing their environment and taking actions to achieve specific goals. They do this by using algorithms that not only follow the same series of steps every time to solve a problem, but are capable of learning by a process of trial and error. ¬†Mike says: ‚ÄúImagine that you were trying to bake a cake but parts of the recipe were missing. We can bake a cake every day and change the recipe a little each time and see how it tasted. Over time, we‚Äôd get closer to a cake that tasted good.
‚ÄúThose are the kinds of processes where we like to apply AI. Ones where our algorithm doesn‚Äôt just do the same thing, but has a way of improving its solution each time it tries and fails.‚Äù
If you‚Äôve played a video game, then you will have played against the game‚Äôs AI in single-player mode. The AI will be programmed to behave differently, depending on the game. ‚ÄúIn a game like The Sims, we want our AI to act more like humans,‚Äù explains Mike. ‚ÄúWe want it to be emotional, make mistakes, to create dramatic stories.
‚ÄúWhereas in a game like Dark Souls [for ages 16+], which is about being an adventurer, we want the AI to be difficult but we don‚Äôt want it to always beat us. We want it to be predictable so we can learn its movements and work out how to defeat it.‚Äù
Read MoreSTEM Challenge #4: Discover the eco-systems on your doorstepThis amazing card trick shows the magic of mathsSTEM Challenge #2: plan a space mission in Earth's solar systemSTEM challenge #1: Make a paper planeAlmost every game we play has some kind of AI, says Mike. Sometimes you notice the AI because it‚Äôs an enemy, for instance. But not all AI controls characters in games. Some of it is making the game design adapt to things we do. ¬†Mike explains what that means in an online multiplayer game like Fortnite: ‚ÄúHere these intelligent algorithms try to guess where you‚Äôre going to move or shoot next, so if there‚Äôs a problem with your internet connection, it still feels to you like the correct thing happened.‚Äù
AI is also used in video games for ‚Äúprocedural generation‚Äù, which is designing the content, the levels and worlds players inhabit. ‚ÄúOne of the big examples of this is Minecraft. Minecraft worlds are created by procedural generation and it‚Äôs the AI doing the game design,‚Äù Mike says.
How to never lose at noughts and crossesWant to impress your friends or family by ¬†never losing at noughts and crosses? In our fifth STEM challenge, we show you how learning a simple set of rules can help you build a winning streak ‚Äî just make sure your opponent doesn‚Äôt learn them too!Noughts and crosses may appear a simple game, yet it‚Äôs used by lecturers at Queen Mary University of London to show school students how computer programs and artificial intelligence work. In fact, one of earliest video games, OXO, developed by Cambridge University computer science professor Sandy Douglas in 1952, used an AI program to play noughts and crosses. ¬†Playing noughts and crosses by following the rules below will help you understand how everything computers do is governed by instructions created by computer programmers. This also prompts the question: can something that follows these instructions be considered intelligent? ¬†We‚Äôve worked with the Game AI Research Group, part of the School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science at Queen Mary University of London on this latest STEM challenge. ¬†Our noughts and crosses challenge is based on an activity co-created by Paul Curzon, professor of computer science in the school, for the Computer Science 4 Fun (cs4fn) project at Queen Mary, which shows how computer science is about solving puzzles, creativity and changing the future. ¬†You will needA piece of paper to write down the rules for never losing at noughts and crossesSome more paper to play noughts and crosses on ‚Äî or, if you have one, a whiteboard you can wipe clean after every gameA pen or pencil, or a whiteboard penSomeone to play against (preferably an opponent who doesn‚Äôt know the rules for never losing a game!The rules for never losing at noughts and crossesOn a piece of paper, write down the following rules ‚Äî which you could also call a computer program or algorithm as they are a set of instructions to be followed. If you can memorise them, you‚Äôve more chance of winning!
Move 1: ¬†Go in a corner. ¬†Move 2: ¬†If the other player did not go there, THEN go in the opposite corner to move 1. ELSE go in a free corner. ¬†Move 3: If there are 2 Xs and a space in a line, THEN go in that space. IF there are 2 Os and a space in a line, THEN go in that space. IF NOT go in a free corner. ¬†Move 4: IF there are 2 Xs and a space in a line, THEN go in that space. IF there are 2 Os and a space in a line THEN go in that space. IF NOT go in a free corner. ¬†Move 5: Go in the free space. ¬†If you follow the rules every game, you will either win or draw ‚Äî never lose. Repeat this process until the other player gets tired of you being the noughts and crosses champion!Why do these rules work?Mike Cook says that noughts and crosses is useful for illustrating how computer programs ¬†and AI work. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a determinist game, meaning you always know what‚Äôs going to happen when you make a move. It‚Äôs also what we ¬†see all the information in the ¬†game at all times, except what the other player is thinking.‚ÄúThe more you play noughts and crosses the more you learn the process by which you can always guarantee a win or a draw. That process is exactly the algorithm you‚Äôve written ¬†down. Most AI comes down to writing some kind of algorithm.‚Äù
However, AI is not just an algorithm that follows that same set of instructions no matter what happens. An AI device is an ‚Äúintelligent agent‚Äù, capable of assessing its environment, learning by trial and error and adapting to solve problems. ¬†So where does the intelligence in AI come from ‚Äî is it from the people who design it or the device itself? This is a big philosophical question that computer scientists are always debating, according to Mike.¬†‚ÄúCertainly a lot of the intelligence comes from the people who write the algorithms, design computer systems and input data that AI uses. But sometimes we can‚Äôt really agree on where the intelligence comes from,‚Äù he says. There are examples of AI algorithms that have come up with solutions that no one would ever have thought of. ¬†‚ÄúWith AI we‚Äôre trying to find ways to give computers the same kind of reasoning, planning and processes we take for granted. The most fun part of building an AI is trying to figure out how to take this knowledge that you have and express it in a way that a computer can understand and use.‚Äù

Title: Artificial intelligence screens war photos to meet EU requirements | Tampere universities - Tampereen korkeakouluyhteis√∂
description: A study by Tampere University uses artificial intelligence (AI) to study photographs from World War II in a multidisciplinary research project whose res...
og:description: A study by Tampere University uses artificial intelligence (AI) to study photographs from World War II in a multidisciplinary research project whose results will help museums and image archives to ...
twitter:description: A study by Tampere University uses artificial intelligence (AI) to study photographs from World War II in a multidisciplinary research project whose results will help museums and image archives to meet the requirements of the EU‚Äôs Web Accessibility Directive. Researchers in various fields will also benefit when AI handles the raw screening of large data.
article text:
ResearchArtificial intelligence screens war photos to meet EU requirementsPublished on 9.12.2020Tampere UniversityMembers of information troops in Vyborg in 1941. TK photograph: Erik BlombergA study by Tampere University uses artificial intelligence (AI) to study photographs from World War II in a multidisciplinary research project whose results will help museums and image archives to meet the requirements of the EU‚Äôs Web Accessibility Directive. Researchers in various fields will also benefit when AI handles the raw screening of large data.‚ÄúOur study has much to offer in terms of accessibility on the one hand and AI and image research on the other,‚Äù says Anssi M√§nnist√∂, university lecturer in visual journalism.
M√§nnist√∂ is a member of research projects related to AI and image analysis of war photos taken during WW2. The starting point is basic research whose results can help the work of digital archives that contain millions of images. The results will benefit memory organisations, such as archives, libraries, museums and research institutes, as well as newspapers, media and image archives owned by private companies.
A solution for museums‚Äô problem with EU Directive
The multidisciplinary research group received funding from the Academy of Finland‚Äôs Intelligent Society Programme for the research project ‚ÄúImproving Public Accessibility of Large Image Archives‚Äù (IPALIA), which uses AI to study the accessibility of large image archives. At Tampere University, three research fields participate in the study: machine learning, information studies and visual culture research.
The project aims to improve public access to large image databases and collections in a way that meets the conditions of the EU‚Äôs Web Accessibility Directive that entered into force in September.
The directive requires that all images that are publicly available online must be accompanied by a textual description of the content. This requirement is a bottleneck for image archives and museums because there are no cheap and efficient methods to do this work. The problem is particularly great for Finnish-language and Finnish image content.
The research project will use materials from the Finnish Wartime Photograph Archive of the Finnish Defence Forces, which contains almost 160,000 photographs taken by the information troops (TK) during the Finnish Winter, Continuation and Lapland Wars captured in 1939‚Äì1945.
According to M√§nnist√∂, the aim of the new research project that is about be launched is to create a model that provides content description for the TK images in accordance with the directive. The same model will also help other museums and image archives to meet the conditions of the directive.
‚ÄúThe purpose is to provide help in a big challenge. The obligation to have descriptive texts is a rather big problem for many museums,‚Äù M√§nnist√∂ says.
M√§nnist√∂ considers the situation to be optimal for AI research because there is a high demand for practical accessibility solutions.
Ideological undertones of war photographs
The captions for images are often written with an emphasis on factors that do not meet the conditions for accessibility. Images from the front may even contain an ideological or propagandistic description of the situation.
AI and algorithms are not neutral either, but in their basic form they extract quantitative information from many images, for example, of individuals, animals, objects, buildings and their numbers.
AI does not tell you directly that the sergeant major and the captain in the photo are in an artillery barrage or in a certain place in their free time. Instead, it can tell, for example, which patterns or objects are in the front or behind the main characters. M√§nnist√∂ is particularly fascinated by the fact that AI is also able to do spatial analysis.
AI produces basic descriptive text, but it is still partly unclear how much it manages to say about the sexes and age groups of the people in the photo and how well it is able to determine, for example, the weather or the season.
‚ÄúWe have a pretty big basic research component. It is not possible to say with certainty how deep we will get, but we are quite sure that we will gain interesting results,‚Äù M√§nnist√∂ says.
The research project has agreed with the Tampere Museum Centre Vapriikki that the model created in the project will be tested with some of Vapriikki‚Äôs materials in the final phase.
‚ÄúThere may be certain special characteristics in the war imagery that are good to analyse and exclude and to examine how generalisable our method is. We are pleased to have this opportunity,‚Äù M√§nnist√∂ notes.
M√§nnist√∂ praises the research project, for example, for the fact that the new Tampere University can, at its best, introduce genuine and new creative multidisciplinary research and problem solving.
In addition to M√§nnist√∂, Postdoctoral Research Fellow Jenni Raitoharju, who studies machine learning and AI, and Associate Professor Sanna Kumpulainen from information studies are involved in the planning and implementation of the IPALIA project.
AI names people and animals in the contents of photographs. As a new feature, it can also distinguish spatial elements. Identifying TK photographers in the study ‚ÄúMachine Learning Based Analysis of Finnish World War II Photographers‚Äù.
WW2 photos are public, but their contents have not been analysed
The Finnish WW2 images have been published for everyone to use, but only a small part of them have been used in eg books. According to M√§nnist√∂, no one still has a precise idea of the totality of the huge material.
‚ÄúThe photos have been published, but I hit a wall while getting acquainted with their number, contents and temporal variation,‚Äù M√§nnist√∂ describes his research experiences.
The idea of using machine learning for the analysis of war images arose when M√§nnist√∂ went through such images while writing a book with historian Ville Kivim√§ki.
In the first phase, M√§nnist√∂ and an international research group conducted an AI based analysis of the war images whose results have been reported in the article ‚ÄúMachine Learning Based Analysis of Finnish World War II Photographers‚Äù. The study is known to be the first of its kind worldwide.
According to M√§nnist√∂, a new dimension of photographic research is introduced in the article, which is the fact that the study distinguishes between basic image sizes such as overview shots, medium shots and close-ups. AI also distinguished where the people in the image are located. These functions can be applied by museums and media houses.
With traditional methods, researchers can browse and observe the quantitative properties of images very slowly, which means that the numbers of images that can be examined are small, only a few hundred or thousand images.
The research group got AI to analyse about 59,000 WW2 images in a short time. The study produced interesting distributions that would have taken months or years to do with other methods.
From war image analysis to photos about covid-19
The analysis of war images will be helpful when M√§nnist√∂ begins studying photographs published in the Helsingin Sanomat (HS) newspaper during the covid-19 pandemic in the KORTE project. According to M√§nnist√∂, the method implemented in the study to identify the mutual distance of the persons in the image in both depth and width is the key to being able to analyse the changes in the distances between people in HS photographs during the pandemic.
In the research project, the character structure of approximately 80,000‚Äì100,000 images will be broken down by machine learning and the interrelationships between image content will be investigated further. In the second phase of the project, qualitative analysis ‚Äì meaning more traditional media research methods ‚Äì will be used. It is not a question of alternative but of complementary methods.
M√§nnist√∂ says that the transition from WW2 images to newspaper images is a tremendous leap into another era. The images of WW2 basically lack all metadata, such as information about the time, place, and camera settings, which in modern cameras are automatically saved to an image file.
The sample of newspaper images will cover a period of 6‚Äì7 months in 2020 and the same months for 2019. AI will screen information from the HS images about the mode in which the images were taken, whether indoors or outdoors, and whether the people are close to each other or far apart. The basic distribution will provide a starting point for qualitative analysis.
Anssi M√§nnist√∂ is excited about new research projects that apply AI, the effects of which can widely extend to the work of researchers, museums and image archives. Photograph: Teemu Launis
Researchers will have more time for their studies
The new opportunities afforded by AI and machine learning are likely to revolutionise research by analysing raw data.
M√§nnist√∂ remembers how in the 1990s, he went through six months of the Time and Suomen Kuvalehti magazines in six research periods in search of images on Islam for his doctoral dissertation.
‚ÄúIt took me months to go through the magazines. I took photocopies and there were no digital cameras,‚Äù M√§nnist√∂ reminisces.
He went through hundreds of images and browsed thousands of pages. Now, he estimates that thanks to AI, a zero could be added to the end of those numbers and a couple of zeros deleted from the time he spent. That time can now be used on the qualitative analysis part.
‚ÄúI find this inspiring because new methods are being developed and it is tested how they could work together in the multidisciplinary study of journalism, communication and history,‚Äù M√§nnist√∂ says.
In the future, huge amounts of data can be processed with the help of AI, and researchers‚Äô time is freed from browsing pages to the actual research analysis.
‚ÄúI cannot say when we are at a mature stage, but we are now taking decisive steps in that direction. There are likely to be setbacks, but I‚Äôm very excited about this method,‚Äù M√§nnist√∂ enthuses.
Text: Heikki Laurinolli
Kateryna Chumachenko, Anssi M√§nnist√∂, Alexandros Iosifidis, Jenni Raitoharju: Machine Learning Based Analysis of Finnish World War II Photographers. IEEE Access 2020.
¬†
¬†
¬†
